front.title: Bookshelf Editor User's Manual
front.author: Walter Scott, Lilia Medvedyeva, Yulin Peng

body.p: The Bookshelf Editor 1.1 is a compact application designed to help you to store, organize and manage links to on-line content.

The user interface has a familiar look of “shelves” filled with “books” representing the URL links to your favorite websites. Locating and accessing your favorite website is as easy and convenient as picking a book from a shelf. All you need to do is to browse the book titles on your virtual shelves and click the book(s) you want to "read".

The Bookshelf Editor provides you with a variety of convenient built-in tools that help you to create your own design and arrangement of shelves and books. The Bookshelf Editor enables you to organize your books in a manner that makes sense to you. Using the Bookshelf Editor you can:

ul.li: Create multiple shelves of various sizes
Group books on related topics by placing them on different shelves
Change the presentation in each individual shelf by adding spaces between books
Add titles to your books
Change book appearance

body.p: The Bookshelf Editor also enables you to export your project in XML or HTML. Once you have exported your bookshelf, you can view it on any computer; you can even email it to a friend.

You can create and export as many bookshelves as you want and dedicate each to a separate project or topic. In addition, you can carry your collection in a flash drive and access it from any web-enabled computer.
The following minimum system requirements apply to the Bookshelf Editor application:

tr.td: 800 x 600 or higher resolution with 256 or more colors
Any Internet connection, although higher-speed connections are preferable

topic.title: Downloading and Installing the Bookshelf Editor

body.p: To download Bookshelf Editor 1.1:

ol.li: On web page http://courses.online-learning.com, log in to your course page.
Under Navigation, click My course.
Click the name of your course.
In the course information page, click the Course downloads link.

On the Course downloads page, click BookshelfEditor11.exe.
The application file BookshelfEditor11.exe is downloaded to your Downloads directory.

body.p: To install Bookshelf Editor 1.1:

ol.li: In the Downloads directory, locate BookshelfEditor11.exe and double-click BookshelfEditor11.exe.
In the Security Warning dialog box, click Run.
In the Bookshelf Editor 1.1 Install dialog box, click Next.
In the next dialog box that opens, select I have read this ... and click Next.

In the next dialog box that opens, click OK.
Bookshelf Editor 1.1 is now installed on your computer.

body.p: Once you have created your bookshelf and all of your books are organized how you want them to be, it is time to export your bookshelf. Exporting your bookshelf transforms your bookshelf into a viewable format.
Below is the description of the file types that you can export using Bookshelf Editor:

ul.li: XML - Stands for Extensible Markup Language. Exporting your bookshelf as an XML Document allows you to modify all of the wording, where text appears, whether text is plain-font, bold or in italics, and so on.

XSL - Stands for Extensible Stylesheet Language. Exporting your bookshelf as an XSL Document allows you to modify the XML stylesheet. That is, you can alter characteristics such as font, text color, letter-size, indentation size, color scheme, and so on.
HTML - Stands for HyperText Markup Language. Exporting your book shelf as an HTML file allows you to view your bookshelf and follow the book-links using an Internet browser.
JPEG - Stands for Joint Photographic Expert Group and it is used as a method for compressing digital images.

body.p: To export your bookshelf file to HTML:

ol.li: In the menu bar, click File > Export Bookshelf.
In the Expert Bookshelf dialog box, ensure HTML Document and JPEG Image File are selected, specify the names for the HTML and JPEG files, and click Export Now.

In the Success dialog box, click OK.
Bookshelf Editor creates an HTML file with the name you specified in the Export Bookshelf dialog box in the directory where you installed Bookshelf Editor 1.1. The name of the export directory appears in the Directory for Export field.

body.p: To export your bookshelf file to XML:

ol.li: In the menu bar, click File > Export Bookshelf.

Select XML Document, specify the names for the XML file, and click Export Now.
Bookshelf Editor creates an XML file with the name you specified in the Export Bookshelf dialog box in the directory where you installed Bookshelf Editor 1.1. The name of the export directory appears in the Directory for Export field.

body.p: To export your bookshelf file to XSL:

ol.li: In the menu bar, click File > Export Bookshelf.

Select XSL Document, specify the name for XSL file, and click Export Now.
Bookshelf Editor creates an XSL file with the name you specified in the Export Bookshelf dialog box in the directory where you installed Bookshelf Editor 1.1. The name of the export directory appears in the Directory for Export field.

body.p: The purpose of the usability test is to evaluate and validate the effectiveness of the Bookshelf Editor manual for end users and to detect errors, defects, and issues in the content of the manual.

The testing group developed the orientation script, the list of tasks and the post-test questionnaires to assist the comprehensive study. The tasks and post testing questions include 6-point evaluation scale and a comment section for taking notes during testing. For the complete set of the test documents, refer to Appendix.

The feedback generated during the usability was all very positive, as it pertains to the user manual content and structure. Most of the criticisms were directed towards the navigational capabilities inherent in viewing a user manual in HTML format. There were a couple small changes to wording and section order that have been made to improve the manual even further, based on the participant feedback. The full list of changes is included in Recommendations.
We are confident that this user manual serves as an excellent reference for operating Bookshelf Editor 1.1.

The Bookshelf Editor is software for storing and organizing URLs. It is provided by Online-learning.com for the course assignments completed during the Professional Technical Writing Course. The tested version of the Bookshelf Editor application is 1.1.
The objectives of the test are to investigate the following:

ul.li: The information presented in the Bookshelf Editor manual is complete and accurate
The manual is helpful to end users in accomplishing the basic tasks
The answers to the specific questions are easy to find
The language used in the manual is clear and concise
The manual instructions contain sufficient amount of detail to successfully complete a specific task
The reference information for commands, controls, options is clear and complete
Provide recommendations on how to improve the manual’s usability

body.p: There are several goals for usability testing:

ul.li: Find people willing to test the software user's manual who are computer literate, but have never seen the software before (participants).
Provide the participants with the same set of tasks to complete in the Bookshelf Editor, using the manual to accomplish each task.
Provide each participant with a consistent testing environment, including how the test is introduced and conducted.
Ask each participant the same questions upon completion of each task and at the end of each session.
Compile the test results to determine the quality and the usefulness of the manual as it currently exists.
Modify the manual as needed to improve usability.

body.p: The test involved adult participants with no previous exposure to Bookshelf Editor 1.1. The test was conducted as a series of one-on-one sessions with live interactions between a tester and a participant according to the test plan. During the test, a tester made careful observations of a participant’s interaction with Bookshelf Editor and user's manual and recorded the participant’s questions, requests, and comments. A tester also solicited clarification on participant issues and remarks. When a participant couldn’t find information in the manual or complete a task, a tester provided a hint. Once a participant completed all test tasks, a tester conducted an interview following the post-test questionnaires.
With the participants gone, the testers formalized the notes they took during the testing.

With the testing completed, the testing group held a series of post-test discussions considering the study findings and analyzing the usability problem areas. Based on the test results, the testing group provided the recommendations for correcting the defects and common usability issues. The testing group implemented the suggested modifications to the Bookshelf Editor Help manual. The final version of the help manual incorporates the changes recommended in the test report and the changes that address the course instructor’s comments.
Participants' Profiles:

The usability testing results showed little variance for all three of the subjects who "volunteered" to assist in the evaluation of the Bookshelf Editor manual. The majority of the relatively few complaints were due to issues relating to the usability testing questions versus the content of the user manual.

The complaints about the user manual content were minor and focused around word choice and the location of a couple sections. Other complaints about the user manual focused on the presentation method of HTML and the navigational features available in the table of contents. All testers preferred to use the index version of the HTML, which includes the table of contents in a sidebar next to the manual contents.

All testers were confused by the term "breadcrumbs", which is listed in the "using this manual" section. Other things that hindered completion of the tasks included the sections involving viewing properties and viewing the HTML code. The sections that included information on saving the bookshelf and on opening the HTML version of the exported bookshelf needed more detail to suggest to the more modestly-skilled users where to locate their files.

The usability testing confirmed that the user's manual is a valuable tool for completing tasks in Bookshelf Editor 1.1. All of the tester's comments were relatively consistent concerning the quality and usefulness of the user's manual. All were confused by the term "breadcrumbs" and they had difficulty navigating the manual when only using the table of contents. Otherwise, aside from a couple small sections that will be renamed, all testers found the instructions in the user's manual to be very helpful for completing the tasks and for learning the product. They also felt that the manual was organized in a logical manner, and it contained straight-forward figures with clear descriptions.

Based on the positive reviews of the documentation content from the test subjects there are not many changes required to improve the quality and usability of the user’s manual. The largest improvement to the user manual would be to make it available as a PDF. PDFs offer a better format for searching and scrolling through the manual. Another option would be for the HTML to include a numbering for the sections and sub-sections in the table of contents.

Changes to improve the content of the manual include renaming the Narrow (Default) book to "narrow (default) book", reworking the awkwardly worded sentences like "Select the book to which you want to apply a color change" and adding missing terms to the index (that is, HTML, title, and exporting). "Breadcrumbs" should be added to the glossary and the description updated in the How to use this manual section. Section 8.2 Exporting to HTML can also be improved by adding a step to clarify the context. The ML Viewer section should be re-labeled so that users understand that it is for viewing XML and HTML code. The section on saving the bookshelf should include directions that specify more explicitly where the files should be saved in order for the links to work and additional clarifications about save vs save as can be made as well. Likewise, the section on viewing HTML should have an example showing where the HTML file is most likely to be found. Learning the Graphical User Interface (GUI) and Downloading and Installing the Bookshelf Editor sections should change places. It may be a good idea to add steps to the Starting Bookshelf Editor section for users who elected not to install a desktop shortcut.

body.p: Hi [the participant's name]
Thank you for agreeing to participate in testing.
I'm [the tester's name] and I will be working with you today, monitoring this session, and taking notes.

The purpose of this test is to determine how useful the Bookshelf Editor manual is for accomplishing typical tasks in the Bookshelf Editor application. Please do not be concerned with achieving results. We are not testing you. You are here to provide us with initial feedback on the manual and to help us detect any problems or errors we may have missed.

Before the beginning of the test, I will provide you with a sheet with a list of tasks to complete in Bookshelf Editor. During the session, you will work through each task, and I will observe you and take some notes. Please note that you are testing the manual, not the software . Please refer to the Bookshelf Editor manual for information on how to complete each task. Also, please consult the manual first if you have any questions related to the software functionality or user interface.

You can ask any question any time, but I may not answer them since we will be testing the usability of the documentation. I would like to encourage you to think out loud as you work through the tasks.

After you complete each task, I’ll ask you to rate how useful the manual was for helping you to perform the task. I will use a 6-point evaluation scale for each task in a list. After you finish the test, I'll ask you a few questions regarding you experience using the manual. You are free to leave at any point during the testing process if you want to.
